p: Food- and water-borne infections are likely to increase and may result in gastrointestinal illness and in some cases chronic health problems ( i.e., kidney failure) [ 14, 48, 49]. Some diseases such as acute gastrointestinal illness (AGI) have been associated with conditions that may be altered by climate change, such as higher temperatures and changing precipitation patterns, respectively [ 49]. Heavy precipitation events, projected to increase in many regions of North America, are strongly correlated to incidence of water-borne diseases [ 48].
